title: 106_s1159
content: Title X of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 is amended to include a new section called "Physical Education for Progress Act." This part aims to provide grants and contracts to local educational agencies to enhance physical education programs for all K-12 students. Physical education is crucial for children's development, improving their health, self-esteem, relationships, behavior, and independence. Physical education is essential for children's development, improving their health, self-esteem, relationships, behavior, and independence. It also helps with weight regulation, bone development, posture, skillful moving, and promotes active lifestyle habits. Participation in high-quality physical education programs can lead to better health and fitness in children. The prevalence of obesity among children in the United States is linked to low levels of physical activity. Physical education programs promote health and fitness, reducing the risk of obesity-related diseases and premature deaths. Physically fit adults have lower risks of heart attacks and stroke. Overweight rates among young people have doubled in the past 30 years, with inactivity contributing to obesity prevalence. Obesity-related diseases cost the US economy over $100 billion annually. Obesity-related diseases cost the US economy over $100 billion annually. Inactivity and poor diet cause at least 300,000 deaths a year. Physically fit adults have reduced risk factors for heart attacks and stroke. Children are not as active as they should be, with fewer than 1 in 4 getting 20 minutes of vigorous activity daily. Surgeon General's 1996 Report and CDC recommend daily physical education for all students. Children are not as active as they should be, with fewer than 1 in 4 getting 20 minutes of vigorous activity daily. The Surgeon General's 1996 Report and CDC recommend daily physical education for all students from kindergarten to grade 12. Twelve years after Congress passed a resolution encouraging quality daily physical education. Twelve years after Congress passed a resolution encouraging daily physical education for all students from kindergarten to grade 12, little progress has been made. Every student in the nation's schools should have the opportunity to participate in quality physical education. Despite the resolution passed by Congress twelve years ago, there has been little progress in providing high-quality daily physical education programs for all students from kindergarten to grade 12. It is essential for every student to have the opportunity to participate in quality physical education to develop health-related fitness, physical competence, and cognitive understanding about physical activity for adopting healthy lifestyles. "SEC. 10999D. PROGRAM AUTHORIZED." The Secretary can award grants to local educational agencies for physical education programs for K-12 students, including equipment, curriculum development, and staff training. "SEC. 10999E. APPLICATIONS; PROGRAM REQUIREMENTS." Each local educational agency must submit an application to the Secretary outlining a plan to enhance physical education programs in schools to meet specific requirements. These requirements include providing elementary, middle, and high school students with a minimum of 150 minutes of physical education curriculum. Physical education programs must provide elementary, middle, and high school students with at least 150 minutes per week of instructional physical education, including fitness education and assessment to improve physical well-being and instruction in various motor skills. Physical education programs should include daily instructional physical education, fitness education, motor skills instruction, cognitive concepts about physical fitness, and opportunities for social development. Physical education programs should enhance the physical, mental, and social development of every child, including cognitive concepts about motor skills, social and cooperative skills, appropriate physical activity, and instruction in healthy eating habits. Physical education programs aim to develop children's physical, mental, and social skills through activities like sports and games. Teachers in this field should have specialized degrees and receive ongoing professional development to stay updated. Teachers of physical education must have baccalaureate degrees as specialists and receive professional development to stay current. Extracurricular activities like team sports and ROTC are not part of the assisted physical education curriculum. The Secretary ensures equitable distribution of grants and contracts between urban and rural local educational agencies, as well as between agencies serving large and small student populations. Private school and home-schooled students are also included in the provisions. The Secretary ensures equitable distribution of grants and contracts between urban and rural local educational agencies, as well as between agencies serving large and small student populations. Private school and home-schooled students can participate in activities funded under this part. An application for funds under this part may include home-schooled and private school children and teachers in activities. SEC. 10999H requires a report for continued funding. SEC. 10999H requires an annual report for continued funding of grants or contracts under this part, detailing activities and progress towards program requirements. The Secretary must submit a report to Congress by June 1, 2003, detailing programs assisted under this part, their success in improving physical fitness, and recommendations for their continuation and improvement. Additionally, not more than 7 percent of grant funds can be used for administrative costs, and there are provisions for the federal share and ensuring funds supplement, not supplant. The Federal share for projects under this part is capped at 90% for the first year and 75% for subsequent years. Funds must supplement, not replace, other Federal, State, and local funds for physical education activities. Authorization of appropriations is outlined in SEC. 10999L. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2000 to 2004 totaling $30,000,000 for 2000, $70,000,000 for 2001, and $100,000,000 for each year from 2002 to 2004 to support physical education activities.
